Rex is an Entomology Major and continues their studies at Ohio State. They continue to work in the Goodell lab, helping on the Specialist Bee Survey in Summer 2024 and 2025. title: Mentoring
text:
Noma Semler

Noma is a current EEOB Masters student at Ohio State University. They first began working with me in 2022 on the Specialist Bee Project. They helped me investigate the nesting habitat of two specialist species and the bee community. They also traveled across the state to survey the hosts of specialist bees. After graduating in 2023 with a degree in Entomology, they were admitted into the graduate program at Ohio State and started working alongside me in the Goodell Lab. Their research focuses on Andrena geranii, a Hydrophyllum specialist, and how its population is influenced by sandy soil.

Hi, welcome to my personal website!
My name is Amber Fredenburg. I am currently a PhD Candidate at The Ohio State University in Dr.¬†Karen Goodell‚Äôs lab studying native ground-nesting bee ecology and conservation. I earned my B.Sc. in Zoology from The Ohio State University in 2018 and a M.Sc. in Forestry from Lakehead University in 2020.
My research interests span ecology and entomology, with a particular emphasis on conservation. I am passionate about understanding how we can support ecosystems, and all the species within them, to live and thrive within human-dominated environments. The projects I have been involved in range from large-scale surveys of Ohio‚Äôs bees (the first in the state!) to small-scale nesting habitat enhancements in urban parks. I have spent much of my time as a researchers developing a deep understanding of native bees, including skills to identify species, but as an ecologist I am also interested in pollinators as a whole, the plants they pollinate, and the other biotic and abiotic factors these species interact with daily.
I am not only a researcher, but also a teacher and mentor. I have taught and led several course lab and recitations including biology, ecology, forest entomology, population genetics, and organismal diversity. I also have had the opportunity to mentoring several students through many research projects, some of which developed independent research! I enjoy getting students involved in research, but also helping them find their place in science.
On this website, you will find details of my research, published works, and mentorship. I will be regularly updating about my research progress and latest work.
Please feel free to contact me.

title: Research
text:
arXiv Preprint
Ground-nesting bees, species that excavate nests in underground in soil, are less diverse and abundant in urban environments, likely due to a lack of nesting habitat because of the many impervious surfaces (roads, buildings, sidewalks) in these areas. However, urban green spaces can be a refuge for wildlife and present an opportunity for conservation, especially for insects which can persist in these small habitat fragments. Planting pollinator gardens and proving foraging resources for bees is a common conservation action, but these actions do not include any nesting resources. We wanted to provide nesting resources for ground-nesting bees in urban areas. Thus, we constructed ‚Äúsoil sanctuaries‚Äù, or soil surface manipulations including bare ground, pebbles, mounded soil, leaf litter (and a control) at 21 locations around Columbus, Ohio at different levels of urbanization.

title: Research
section: Using specialist species to investigate the role of nest resources on bees across ecological scales
text:
Using specialist species to investigate the role of nest resources on bees across ecological scales

Specialist bees, bees that forage from one or few plant species, present a unique opportunity to help us understand ground-nesting bee nesting habitat because we can account for the influence of floral resources on their populations. I surveyed the host plants of two ground-nesting specialist bee species, Andrena erigeniae (Claytonia virginca specialist) and Melissodes desponsus (Thistle specialist). We then investigate the local and landscape features that may provide nesting resources to these species. We also surveyed the bee community, to compare different scales of bee responses to these nesting resources. The comparison from population to functional community to entire community shows how species-level habitat associations may be masked by dominant taxa at broader ecological scales. This work not only provides a deep understanding of two ground-nesting bees, showing us just how different their nesting habitats can be. Our findings emphasize that understanding and conserving bee diversity requires a dual approach that captures broad community patterns while also explicitly addressing the ecological needs of less common or more specialized species.

title: Research
section: The effects of geologic history and soil characteristics on the bee community across Ohio
text:
The effects of geologic history and soil characteristics on the bee community across Ohio

Most bees (80%) nest underground, excavating tunnels in the soil. Despite their prevalence, little is known about where they nest. We conducted Ohio‚Äôs first statewide bee survey, to investigate how soil characteristics across Ohio influence bee diversity and composition. Ohio is an interesting study location because during the Pleistocene, large glaciers swept through half of the state, resulting in markedly different topography and soil characteristics. We evaluate how glaciation shifted the soil characteristics important for bee nesting and how those characteristics influence the bee communities.

title: Research
text:
The Ohio Bee Survey

Ohio lacked a systematic survey of bee species, which is important for establishing baseline data that will help us monitor bee populations. In 2020, The Goodell Lab conducted Ohio‚Äôs first statewide bee survey with the help of a network of volunteers. We collected, identified, organized and cataloged over 50,000 specimens. This data will not only be used as a baseline for future monitoring, but it will also be used to evaluate large scale effects of landscape on bee community diversity and composition. We will also investigate how backyards and parks support bee communities. We used this information to provide the Ohio Department Of Natural Resources the first list of bee species of conservation.

title: Research
text:
The Specialist Bee Project

After conducting the Ohio Bee Survey, The Goodell Lab wanted to further search for rarer species we may have missed with our initial survey. From 2021-2025 we surveyed for specialist bees, species with limited floral hosts, across Ohio, in search of rare species and species with particular habitat requirements. We surveyed the host flowers of specialist species and non-host flower species to better understand how flowers support the bee community. This information will help us develop monitoring strategies that capture high diversity but fewer bees.
